title: FL-170 - Declaration for Default or Uncontested
question: FL-170, #5 - Declaration of Disclosure
question_tags: Dissolution of marriage,Alimony,Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Family law,Default judgment
answers:
Whether you are proceeding by 'default' or as an uncontested action depends on whether the other party filed a response to the petition for dissolution of marriage. If she has not responded, then you are proceeding by default (you should have also filed a request to enter default), and you should check the default box (B if you have a signed agreement and A if you do not). Otherwise, you should check C.

Whether the other two pages are left blank depends on the issues that were possibly before the court, not what happened to them. So if you agreed that your community assets have been awarded one way or the other, or that spousal support has been waived, you should still check these boxes.

Best of luck to you.

Edna is the dean, she is always correct and gives good advice. She helps people by doing limited scope agreements and motions, those are papers filed by the public but generated by attorneys at far below the cost of having one appear in court.
Yes. Also use the form where you can BOTH sign. Appearance declaration and waiver.
